ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 4 hours
Most weeks hardly any time but then a lot at the end for the final project.
I probably spent one hour per week outside the classroom on this course.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: B-
great emergency perspective
Great course that is incredibly practical. It was great to get background on how the different systems and components work. It covered all the basics.

Really enjoyed working on the VMOC--would be interesting if we could meet or communicate with some of the Tulane students as well.The VMOC experience was a very practical and excellent exercise to be a part of.Would prefer more kinesthetic learning experiences--more roundtables, more discussions, more working through situations as though we were in an EOC to apply what we learn to simulations.The final project experience was really a great one to work on--being pushed to work on practical applications of what we learn in class and in the public health world is helpful

This class was interesting, although the instructors should do a better job at explaining what they're looking for with various assignments. We felt that we didn't have too much guidance throughout the semester

I was extremely excited for this course, and unfortunately my high expectations were not met. Both instructors are fantastic and have fascinating and valuable experiences to share. The active exercises (virus outbreak scenario, sticky notes&tape, final table top exercise)we did were excellent--engaging and instructive-- and I only wish we had done more. I did not feel the online trainings were very helpful and the lectures were dry and probably not the best way to convey information. I wish there had been more active learning and more personal anecdotes/lessons from the instructors.The final project was challenging and the instructions were vague, but I did learn a lot from the process of doing it.

The course provided an overview of the role of public health and its practitioners in emergency and disaster response situations. Much of the material was based off of the same fundamental tenets, and since it was focused on the role of public health, many of the learned responsibilities were similar from situation to situation. This class provided a good opportunity to learn about the federal, state and local responsibilities in responding to emergencies.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  She is very knowledgeable but most the topics are mostly irrelevant to public health
Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  very understanding

Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  She was knowledgeable but the course was basically taught by Joanne McGovern. She was incredibly knowledgeable and experienced which made the course even more fantastic. She could teach us basics and give us examples of things that took place.

Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  Sandy and Joanne clearly are knowledgeable and experienced in this field. Would like to learn more about their experiences. They provided useful feedback--doing the trainings was also really informative!

Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  Sandy--a little quiet, often working on her computer, but when she did contribute it was always very valuable.Joanne--great rapport with the students, lots to learn from her

Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  Dr. Bogucki was very knowledgeable about the intricacies of the public health role in disaster and emergency response. LTC McGovern took on much of the role of instruction in the second half of the class, and her experience in the field was a valuable resource. Both instructors did a good job of elucidating vague points, as sometimes the material could be somewhat abstract. They both did a good job facilitating the projects that were completed throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: A+. Dalton's only responsibility was to take attendance, but he did a great job of it.
needed office hours
While he was in class every week and responded to email, it did not seem like he did anything else.
I think the TA could be utilized more in this class, especially if there were scenarios that we more frequently had to participate in.

Micheal Dalton did absolutely nothing all term. He sat silently (save for the occasional scoff) and played with his iPad. This is not exaggeration, I honestly cannot remember a single helpful thing he did all term except pass out a sign-in sheet for attendance.
Dr. Dalton was available to take questions outside of class and helped provide midterm evaluations, which was appreciated.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: great to take if medschool or PH agency bound
Great course, practical. Gives training in the FEMA courses and models the EOC and ESF#8
If you are interested in emergency planning and disaster preparedness, take this course.
The course had so much potential and if revised, could be truly excellent. The instructors are incredibly valuable but the lecture style of the course is not very engaging or helpful.

I would recommend this course for anybody interested in the subject matter, as the instructors were valuable resources and clearly knew what they were doing. Feedback was somewhat limited throughout the course, so it was sometimes difficult to gauge how you were doing in the course. Otherwise, it was a very interesting and interactive course.
